repnme.cdata!:
Russian Federation - Municipal Water and
            Wastewater Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Municipal Water and Wastewater
            Project for Russian Federation had a moderately satisfactory
            and a moderate risk to development outcome. Both the Bank
            and the borrower performances were moderately satisfactory.
            Findings of the project include: There was strong support
            for the most critical and immediate investments needed to
            improve the operation of the water and wastewater systems.
            There was limited improvement of system operations,
            reduction of operational costs and improvement of service
            quality and there were some improvements related to
            institutional and commercial reforms aimed at improving
            physical system operations and financial performance of
            vodokanals. The main lessons learned from the project are:
            A) Project objectives should be closely tailored to the
            capacity of the government and related agencies to implement
            the Project and to the conditions of the enabling
            environment existing at the time of Project preparation. B)
            Small borrowers pay a relatively large cost to comply with
            conventional Bank fiduciary requirements. C) Reform of water
            supply and wastewater services provision and utility
            management is a long and continuous process.

repnme.cdata!:
Russian Federation - Municipal Water and
            Wastewater Project - environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Municipal Water and Wastewater
            Project in Russia, aims to arrest the decline of water, and
            wastewater services in fourteen medium-size cities.
            Regardless of its beneficial environmental effects in the
            long-run, adversity is nonetheless expected to occur during
            construction, due to inappropriate disposal of excavation
            materials, construction debris, and small amounts of
            hazardous wastes and materials, in addition to noise
            disturbances, dusting, and traffic disruption. This
            environmental assessment reviews each project city
            separately, and provides an environmental baseline.
            Mitigation is largely addressed in the procurement
            documents, which include contract clauses for safe keeping,
            in and around construction sites, to minimize dusting
            through the use of sprinklers, to limit construction to
            day-time working schedules only, minimizing noise
            disturbances, and to restore vegetation following
            construction, subject to inspection, and compliance with the
            Russian Law on Environmental Expertise. Sludge deposits, and
            effluents, particularly in the city of Gagarin, contain
            critical concentrations of phosphorus, and nitrogen
            compounds, such as ammonia and nitrate, which should be
            treated by process-integrated measures, and sludge treatment
            systems. By and large, components with significant adverse
            environmental impacts (construction budget of over $0.5
            million) shall be subject to review by the Department of
            State Ecological Expertise, to ensure compliance with
            environmental legislation.

repnme.cdata!:
Russian Federation - Municipal Water and
            Wastewater Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Municipal Water and Wastewater
            Project aims to arrest the decline of water, and wastewater
            services of medium-size cities that have demonstrated
            commitment to project objectives, and institutional reforms,
            in various regions in Russia. The project components are as
            follows. 1) The Immediate Investment Program (IIP) selection
            criteria include those investments whose a) scope, and
            benefits are defined by the preparation stage; b) priority
            stands on a technical, and service quality perspective; c)
            capacity to achieve service improvements is proven; and, d)
            improvements are liable to reduce operating costs, and
            upgrade services. IIP investments will replace pumping
            equipment, rehabilitate water and wastewater treatment
            plants, specific sections of water mains, and contaminated
            water intakes. 2) The Management Strengthening and
            Operational Improvement Program will implement a set of
            governance, and technical/commercial reforms, to improve
            physical system operations, management, and financial
            performance, providing hardware/software tools, as well as
            technical assistance, and training. It includes the
            introduction of macro, and master metering, leak management,
            and water supply network optimization. 3) Project management
            support will assist in the development of final designs,
            procurement, construction supervision, including assistance
            to the project unit, and auditing.

Russian Federation - Municipal Water and
